title: Will the peace agreement between Colombia and the FARC win approval in the upcoming national plebiscite?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
This is not Dewey beats Truman... link here http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-37537252
The fighting has gone on far too long.   Also, the government will be more considerate to FARC positions.

No leads 50.23% to 49.76% in favor, with 99.59% of voting stations reporting.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-colombia-peace-idUSKCN12204M?il=0 BBC plebiscite failed.  BBC also points out that the FARC / Colombian government agreements were dependent on passage of the plebiscite.
There never was a "final agreement", signed or otherwise.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-37537252
No has 55.22% with 99% of votes counted. It's unfortunate , low vote count in general has made the right win the vote .

From Reuters:
"With results in from 90.66 percent of voting stations, the "no" vote was marginally ahead at 50.10 percent, versus 49.89 percent for "yes," according to Colombia's election authority."
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-colombia-peace-idUSKCN12204M?il=0
Rejection of the agreement would lead to a continuation of decades of war something which Colombians should acknowledge. They are not going to get a settlement which everyone will like
TV last night said the for is 55 vs 36% no
It would resolve 50 years of  suffering.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/colombian-peace-plan-heads-for-plebiscite-1472166364 the plebiscite would pass if only 13% of population comes out to vote and more than half of that vote yes (?!) Crazy interpretation of majority rule, imo But why I 'm on the other side of gj consensus here is due to:
- Santos popularity at moment is well below 30%
- agreement between government and FARC seems really rushed through, These were not the only two groups involved in the past 50 years of strife. I think the population will read this as too many concessions given to FARC 
- Justice is an important issue in a plebiscite and government has not given it enough of the stage.
The country is progressing economically and there is a hope that peace will build up prosperity

The "final agreement" still is not resolved. Unfortunately the written document, finally signed last week between the FARC and the Colombian government, still has not resulted in a "final agreement".   Why?  The written agreement is only a part of the FARC demands for a "final agreement". One additional "demand" by the FARC for a "final agreement" was the inclusion of the provisions in the constitution, in order to prevent (or at least make it more difficult) for a future government to change the laws.  The Courts indicated that a referendum was required in order to amend the constitution: hence the vote on October 2nd. This week's Economist points out the difference in the following article: http://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21707921-all-its-imperfections-and-complexities-agreement-between-government-and-farc
"One of the criticisms of the agreement is that it will be incorporated into the constitution. This was something that the FARC insisted on, following the Colombian habit of trying to write everything into law rather than trusting in political guarantees. .....  “It’s a transitional article to guarantee that future governments comply with the agreements." The October 2nd vote may or may not be the final step in the "final agreement" between the FARC and the Colombian government, but it at least is another step in the right direction.  If the referendum fails, there is no final agreement.  The result would be a signed agreement that does not meet the FARCs requirements and is changable by future governments (for example a future Uribe gov't.).  The Santo's government and the FARC chose to hold the official signing before the referendum to provide positive news to increase the chances of passage.  It is possible that there may be other unresolved issues that may become appearent later........to be continued...

gonna be a wet day across Colombia tomorrow, and especially in three of ten most densely populated cities; but not likely to keep <13% from turning up:

Polls continue to show clear lead for yes, and consensus is at 99%. One survey, conducted by polling firm Ipsos on behalf of local media RCN Radio, RCN Television, La FM radio and Semana magazine, showed 66 percent of those voting would approve the deal, while 34 percent would vote against it. Another poll by Datexco, published by newspaper El Tiempo and W Radio, estimated that 55 percent of Colombians will vote “yes” in the referendum and 36.6 percent will vote “no.”
To make the vote’s result binding, the winning side needs a majority of votes cast and support totalling at least 13 percent of the country’s 33 million eligible voters.
http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/222172/colombians-expected-to-say-%E2%80%98yes%E2%80%99-to-peace

"The trauma inflicted on Kabul’s residents are still fresh in the minds of those that lived through the harrowing experience, even as Ghani’s government seeks to provide amnesty to a man who caused considerable pain and much bloodshed. To add insult to injury, the agreement seeks to give Hekmatyar an active voice and participation in the government. The return of Hekmatyar to Kabul will likely resurface physical and psychological pain to those who suffered from his war crimes."
http://thediplomat.com/2016/09/ghanis-deal-with-the-devil-hekmatyar-and-transitional-justice/
There will be peace in our time.

The government was succesful in presenting the deal as an act of strenght not weakness. Country is in good economic shape, what makes population as a whole look for solutions to serious problems like the multidecade civil war.

Most opinion polls suggest "yes" in the upcoming national refrendum although the popularity of the "Yes" vote has come down slightly. The undecided vote in these samples is of worry and could swing the vote in favour of  "No". Hence i am going with 95% as opposed to a 100%

After 50 years of conflict, as well as previous agreements with different armed groups and the Columbian government, shows the high probability of the deal going through. A growing economy with relative drops in crime has put the Columbian people on the path of voting in favor of the deal. Barring some gaffe by the ruling party and, thus, delivering an easy win to the opposition, the deal should be signed and approved by the populace.

The Latest: Colombia, FARC Rebels Sign Historic Peace Accord
http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/09/26/world/americas/ap-lt-colombia-peace-ceremony-the-latest.html By THE ASSOCIATED PRESSSEPT. 26, 2016, 7:58 P.M. E.D.T. CARTAGENA, Colombia — The latest on the signing of a historic peace deal in Colombia (all times local): Colombia's government and the country's largest rebel movement have signed a historic peace accord ending a half-century of bloody combat. President Juan Manuel Santos and Rodrigo Londono, leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, signed the 297-page agreement before a crowd of 2,500 foreign dignitaries and special guests in the Caribbean city of Cartagena. Monday's deal must still be ratified in an Oct. 2 referendum. If it passes, as is widely expected, the rebels will turn over their weapons to United Nations-sponsored observers in the next six months while forming a political party. The FARC will be guaranteed a minimum 10 seats in congress over the next two legislative periods. Opponents have criticized the deal for sparing guerrilla leaders jail time if they confess to war crimes.

Today's signing of the "final peace agreement" between the FARC and the Columbian government, will use actual pens and ink.
The attached link has a photo of one of the pens, made from spent bulllet casings.
http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/26/americas/colombia-farc-peace-deal/
A good many people are not too happy about this deal with FARC (letting them off too lightly).

Land reform remains a troublesome issue and polling results have been very skewed "in favor" of passage in the national plebiscite. This link from El Pais english version in Madrid offers helpful background http://elpais.com/elpais/2016/09/26/inenglish/1474883844_556723.html

There is still lots of people who get manipulated by the churches advice, and is there where lots of people will get influence and will vote "No". Also Uribe Velez has still lots of followers who are voting "NO". My bias/optimistic vote is for a YES, but after Brexit I think you need to listen the so call minorities...they can give surprises

Past electoral results
Latest opinion polls suggesting peace is desired at a reasonable cost
Last four years have shown the process is difficult to be put under serious pressure.
Opposition has played its role but its message seems not strong enough

Santos and others are giving stark warnings of the potential consequences of a No vote. This is obviously anecdotal and a bit of a generalization, but from my time and experience in Colombia, people are ready to put the 80's and 90's to sleep for good. Unless some sort of public attack or significant kidnapping by ELN or some fringe narco- elements of FARC positioning for post-plebiscite control of former FARC revenue streams occurs, I don't see this being voted down. And after just glancing at the graph/ stats on this forecast I see I'm probably not telling other forecasters anything they don't already believe

Let us all hope the people of Columbia have had enough with FARC, and are willing to bring peace to the country.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The metal gold- that is the problem in the future

This is the only change for the Colombians to achieve a lasting peace after 50 years of conflict. The "salt of the earth" people are tired of this protracted war. And finally, the world is watching & supporting this achievement!
Recent polls suggest it will overwhelmingly pass. E.g. http://www.semana.com/noticias/plebiscito-por-la-paz/104205
Reports are of a strong plurality of support
People are tired of >50 years of civil war; people in general are risk-averse and know that voting against the plebiscite will cause even more violence for a long period of time.
Will the citizens of Colombia vote to end violence? Of course.
The fatigue felt by the populace looking for an end to the violence is going to result in approval.  Most everyone who has a voice, left or right will fall into line for a yes vote.
The FARC and Columbian public are sick of this war and the US policy has shifted, as has US funding for the Columbian war on drugs.  It's over.

Recent opinion polls put the "Yes" vote ahead, though the latest -- released Friday by pollster Datexco -- found support had fallen by 9.5 percentage points, to 55.3 percent, since the previous week. The "No" camp had 38.3 percent, it found.
http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2016/09/18/colombia-farc-rebels-meet-vote-peace-deal

Seems a done deal indeed. However polls are unreliable and voters might not turn up. Somebody might pull a trump card just days before the referendum. I feel there is a margin of error. putting it at 80%.

Although the majority of Colombians welcome the end of hostilities, many are very angry at the terms of the settlement.  Law-abiding Colombians are very unhappy with what they view as the overly-generous terms of the settlement, which gives each FARC guerrilla fighter several thousand dollars.  This money comes out of the pockets of Colombian tax-payers, many of whom have lost family members in the decades-long war with the FARC.  I suspect this deal will break down and we willsee some of the FARC go back to terrorism and drug-dealing.

Suspect the GJOpen Judges may be the only hedgehogs NOT attending the "final peace agreement" signing on Sept. 26th (a few links are listed below, however there are actually hundreds if anyone cares to look for them :( National plebiscite will pass.  Too many power players involved, including the Pope, JKerry, Santos, Cuba, etc.
An earlier article covering this topic (from memory, no link) indicated that most of the Colombians with hard feelings against the FARC dwell in the countryside.  Residents of the cities generally have not had the difficult personal history with the FARC, and are more likely to support the (as yet unsigned) agreement.   It seems possible that as important as this agreement is to Santos (years of negotiations), there may be an inclination to make voting easier for the city dwellers as opposed to the anti-FARC crown out in the countryside.  SO there should be some suspicion as to the vote totals. Peace agreement is due to be signed Sept. 26: "Perhaps it is the most important announcement I have made in my life: Peace will be signed next September 26 here in Cartagena," Santos told an assembly of the Colombian Confederation of Chambers of Commerce.

It is Colombia's distraction.  Long dragging issue when outside challenges are more imperative.

A recent puff piece hyping the success of "Plan Colombia" by longtime WaPo pundit Nick Miroff suggests that this is a "done deal". But smart bombs, drones and high tech weaponry that have weakened FARC do not guarantee the referendum will pass.  Article link here from France 24 raises question of whether the hastily called referendum will further divide nation.  http://www.france24.com/en/20160825-colombia-peace-deal-bitter-referendum-fight-santos-uribe Here is link to Miroff https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/plan-colombia-how-washington-learned-to-love-latin-american-intervention-again/2016/09/18/ddaeae1c-3199-4ea3-8d0f-69ee1c Uribe still has credibility. And there are other international factors that figure in on this problm.  Also, it has been a long hard slog for Santos and that has taken a toll on his stamina and dynamism.

Preliminary number.  Usually when people have a chance to vote about not getting killed any more, they are all for it.  My impression from folks who live there is that most of Uribe's support is from less populated places, but I'd feel better about that if I check on it some more.  Stay tuned.
